intro: Gleadovia mupinensis, commonly known as the Mupin mountain bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of New Guinea. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its striking, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale blue. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments at high altitudes, often in rocky or forested areas. Its leaves are broad and ovate, with a smooth texture, and it produces small, elongated fruits that contain numerous seeds. Gleadovia mupinensis is of interest to botanists due to its unique adaptations to its high-altitude habitat.
